It suggests NATO leaders are unlikely to find domestic backing for troop deployments or increases in defence spending to assist the war effort.

Following the dramatic delay of a critical US support package for Ukraine earlier this year, a political shift in Europe towards populist parties of the far-right, and the recent intensification of Russian military attacks against critical infrastructure in Ukraine, the report found that there has been no discernible collapse of morale in Ukraine or change in support for the Ukrainian war effort among its European allies.

It reveals, almost two and half years into Russia's invasion of the country, that a majority of Ukrainians (58%) believe they can secure a battlefield victory, and that confidence in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and the country's president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, remains high. However, there are major divisions in Ukraine when it comes to prospective trade-offs that could bring an end to the conflict.

The study's authors and foreign policy experts, Ivan Krastev and Mark Leonard, believe looming divergences of opinion between European and Ukrainian publics could make finding agreement on how the war should end extremely challenging - and have significant impacts on Kyiv's pathway to NATO and EU accession.

Leonard, co-author and founding director of the European Council on Foreign Relations, told this site: "Our new polling suggests that one of the key challenges for Western leaders will be reconciling the conflicting positions between Europeans and Ukrainians on how the war will end. While both groups recognise the need for continued military provision, to help Ukraine push back at Russian aggression, there is a profound gulf around what constitutes a victory - and what the purpose of Europe's support actually is.

"While Europeans predominantly see a negotiated settlement as the most likely outcome, Ukrainians are not yet ready to countenance territorial trade-offs for NATO accession, nor engage with the idea of 'Finlandisation', in which they would keep their territory but forgo their EU and NATO ambitions."

The report is based on a public opinion poll of adult populations (aged 18 and over) conducted in May 2024 in 15 countries (Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Germany, Great Britain, Greece, Italy, Poland, Portugal, the Netherlands, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, and Ukraine). The total number of respondents was 19,566.

The poll was conducted online by Datapraxis and YouGov in the Czech Republic (9-16 May, 1,071 respondents), France (9-20 May, 1,502),Germany (9-17 May, 2,026), Great Britain (9-13 May, 2,082), Greece (1-16 May, 1,093), Italy (9-17 May, 1,036), Poland (9-23 May, 1,550), Portugal (9-20 May, 1,070), the Netherlands (9-15 May, 1,014), Spain (9-17 May, 1,508), Sweden (9-23 May, 1,026), and Switzerland (2-15 May, 1,079).
summary: A new report by the European Council on Foreign Relations (ECFR) reveals sustained public support in Europe for supplying weapons to Ukraine, but highlights divisions on how the war should end and the purpose of European aid. Published ahead of the 2024 NATO Summit, the report suggests NATO leaders may struggle to gain domestic support for troop deployments or increased defense spending. Despite recent political shifts in Europe and intensified Russian attacks, Ukrainian morale and support from European allies remain strong. The report, based on a May 2024 poll of 19,566 adults across 15 countries, shows that 58% of Ukrainians believe in a battlefield victory and maintain high confidence in President Zelenskyy and the Armed Forces. However, there are significant differences between European and Ukrainian views on ending the conflict, with Europeans favoring a negotiated settlement and Ukrainians rejecting territorial trade-offs for NATO accession. The findings indicate potential challenges for Western leaders in reconciling these conflicting positions, which could impact Ukraine's path to NATO and EU membership.

title: America's gerontocrats are more radical than they look
body:
A conservative writer argues that his country's rulers exhibit the vices of youth, not old age

The discombobulated performance that President Joe Biden gave at the first presidential debate on June 27th sent Democratic Party loyalists, and the journalists who staff the television stations they watch, into a state of shock. It shouldn't have.

Biden's condition has been no mystery to those who work closely with him, nor to daily reporters who have had ever less access to his ever less frequent public appearances. His administration has been marked by malapropisms, confabulations and confusion. "Incidents" have multiplied of late - staring emptily amid a frenzy of gospel music and dancing on the White House lawn in mid-June, "freezing" on stage before being led off by former president Barack Obama at a Hollywood fundraiser. Indeed, the Biden who appeared before more than 50m Americans at the debate has been with us for quite some time.

One telling moment came at a February campaign rally in Las Vegas, as Biden tried to rouse the crowd with a story about a summit in Cornwall in 2021. "Right after I was elected", he began, "I went to a 7 meeting in southern England. And I sat down and said, 'America is back!' and Mitterrand from Germany - I mean France - looked at me and said, 'How long you back for?'" Biden might well have asked the same of François Mitterrand, president of France at the end of the cold war. After all, Mitterrand had been dead since 1996.

A few days later, surprised by a question at a tightly controlled press conference, he seemed to confuse Egypt's Abdel Fattah al-Sisi with the president of Mexico. The press conference had been hastily called after a Justice Department report found that Biden had mishandled classified documents, a criminal offence. The prosecutor declined to press charges only because the president, whom he called "a sympathetic, well-meaning, elderly man with a poor memory", was someone no jury would think capable of committing a crime "that requires a mental state of wilfulness".

It would be natural under the circumstances for voters to ask some uncomfortable questions. If the president lacks the wilfulness to store a document properly, how would he find the power of concentration to manage a multi-front war, or the command of detail to balance a budget, or the common sense to know which foreign leaders to trust? Biden is the oldest president in American history, and the oldest candidate ever to stand for the office.

Voters can throw him out, of course. But the gaffes of the debate bring a deeper problem into focus. Looming behind an adjacent podium that Thursday night was Donald Trump - at 78 years old the second oldest candidate ever to stand, and one to whom various other unflattering superlatives have been attached.

What happened? Americans have come to realise that their country is no longer the youthful and forward-looking society it took itself for in the Clinton, Bush junior and Obama years. It is faced with a choice between two ancient and unpopular politicians, which increasingly feels like the only kind of leader America has. Until last year the country's most powerful legislative post, speaker of the House, was also held by its oldest-ever-occupant, 82-year-old Nancy Pelosi. Senate minority leader Mitch McConnell is 82 as well. The Republican delegation to the powerful Senate Budget Committee is led by 90-year-old Chuck Grassley of Iowa, who was elected during the Carter administration.

Such an elderly profile for the Senate is not wholly regrettable. The upper chamber is supposed to be a place of tradition, good manners and bipartisan comity - and voters tend to like it that way. Unfortunately the loudest and most social-media-savvy parts of the public are an exception. When Democratic senator Dianne Feinstein embraced Republican senator Lindsey Graham to congratulate him on a well-run confirmation hearing in 2020, her own party's Twitter activists demanded she leave the Senate. They got their wish last autumn when she died in office at the age of 90.

We have heard about "gerontocracies" - societies ruled by elders far past their prime, out of touch and yet untouchable, preserving a frozen system from some previous era. They make for pitiable scenes: China in the last confused years of Mao Zedong and Zhou Enlai in the early 1970s; or the Soviet Union a decade later, ruled in turn by Leonid Brezhnev on his deathbed, Yuri Andropov on his dialysis machine, and Konstantin Chernenko struggling to catch his breath in public. China and the , of course, were dictatorships. Their leaders naturally resisted being replaced. But that's partly what makes it so alarming to see the United States failing to inject fresh blood into the body politic.

Most societies have been inclined, or liable, to be ruled by older people. Up to a point this is common sense: the old, we assume, have experience and wisdom. The Roman senate that gives its name to ours derives from the word senex, or "old man". The Spartan senate was called the Gerousia - a name meaning "council of elders" that has occasionally been used by the Greek republic for its upper house, most recently in the 1920s and 1930s. Its members were called gerontes - again, "old men". In town government, our good English word alderman originally carried the sense of "elder" or "patriarch" or "head of clan". Lest we forget, the most important task for a state is survival, and an old person is someone who has managed that, at least.

Old leaders have also been thought useful for reviving old ways, or preserving customs under threat. That's the role Konrad Adenauer - der Alte, "the old man" - played in post-war Germany for almost two decades. Already 68 years old when he emerged from a Nazi prison at the end of the second world war, Adenauer became chancellor at 73. "No experiments!" was one of his campaign slogans. His shell-shocked voters were grateful for the connection he represented to a Germany that had not known Nazism. So grateful, in fact, that they sent Adenauer to Bonn for three more terms as chancellor. In the early 1960s, when the Beatles were playing their first gigs in Hamburg, Germany was still being ruled by an octogenarian born 13 years before Hitler.

Seniors are, admittedly, often short on vim and aggression, qualities that are indispensable to self-defence. But the hope is that this lack might be compensated by wisdom and a cool head. The inclination to violence that marks many men between adolescence and their early 30s can be an advantage in a martial era. But it isn't always, and whether in wartime or peacetime it should be allowed to subside before a leader takes the control of a nation with an army. Andrew Peabody, a Harvard clergyman and classicist from the age of the 19th-century railroad barons, described aged rulers' role as that of "brakemen" on the state's passions.

Slower can be better. Journalists were hard on Ronald Reagan for napping daily (and occasionally even during meetings with dignitaries, most famously with Pope John Paul II in Rome in 1982). But ideally a president should not be sleep-deprived, working overtime, or simply too harried to take a bit of shuteye when he needs it. In his classic account of 19th-century central banking, "Lombard Street", Walter Bagehot claimed that we should celebrate - not resent - the unchallenging work by which bankers grow rich. Do you want your banker to be investing your savings in ventures so complicated that he must burn the midnight oil to manage them? Of course not. Such matters are too important. "The business of banking ought to be simple," Bagehot wrote. "If it is hard it is wrong." This is not to say that a lack of vigour is an asset - only that statesmanship conforms better than we usually think to an old man's energy level.

At the same time, the old are often free agents in a way young people cannot be. Plutarch, who considered envy "the greatest evil attending the management of public affairs", approved of old rulers on the grounds that they were less susceptible to it. The old can thus more easily form dynamic alliances. With most of their careers behind them, they are unlikely to be careerists. They can be reckless in the service of truth, at least as they see it - a vital quality in an age of speech codes and self-censorship.

But there is a darker view of having old people in power, which mirrors a dark view of old people more generally: they have lost touch with their fellow citizens. Joe Biden, for instance, is older than 97% of Americans. This threatens to be especially alienating in a time of rapid social and technological change, because old people tend to adapt poorly. Biden says "ain't" and "y'all" when he talks to black people, in what he seems to think is a sign of empathy. He addresses America's union workers as if they all still work on assembly lines in automobile plants, whereas today half of unionised workers are in the public sector, and many of those in the private sector are employed by government-adjacent companies: utilities, transport and education.

A novelty of our age is that, since technology creates certain predictable problems (protecting privacy online, climate change, regulating drone traffic), a democracy can be divided into two classes of citizens. There are young ones, who will have to live with the consequences of a problem, and older ones, to whom that problem might be outright invisible. This has not been a failing of Biden's administration, which has designed, and muscled through Congress, vast government programmes meant to establish green-energy infrastructure and restore American competitiveness in microchip manufacturing. But even when it is politically competent, the domination of a country's politics by old people can be evidence of some deeper problem, some uncomfortable sociological reality that is disrupting the usual system of generational succession and blocking the rise of the young.

The Soviet gerontocracy of the early 1980s, for instance, was fallout from the Stalinist purges of the late 1930s. Brezhnev, Andropov and Chernenko had all, as young men, been among the communist cadres who proved themselves trustworthy - or at least managed to survive at a time when many of their colleagues wound up in the gulag or an early grave. The second world war introduced a crop of heroes whose claims on public loyalty had little to do with the party programme - Marshal Georgi Zhukov conspicuous among them. In most societies a genial soldier like Zhukov would be promoted. In Stalin's, he was considered a rival and marginalised. The pre-war generation circled the wagons, and by 1980, Russia was led by a doddering core born before the first world war. Andropov, the most original among them, decided Mikhail Gorbachev was a trustworthy enough Leninist to be introduced as a voting member of the Politburo, even if he was a raw youth of 49.

The United States owes its present leadership crisis to a similar generational logjam, albeit one with a different and more benign mechanism. The American baby boom, which lasted from 1946 to 1964, was larger than its European equivalents. By the early 1980s all its members were old enough to vote, and they made up roughly 40% of the country's electorate for decades. This made the baby-boomers politically invincible on any question where the generation had a strong preference. Their whims became laws. In the 1950s, the boomers' parents presided over a huge increase in the country's education budget, which, by the time the youngest boomers graduated, would see university enrolments quintuple.

The circumstances of the 1960s - in other words, luck - did a great deal to empower the boomers as a generation. They had nothing to do with devising the war in Vietnam, but they were the first to protest against it, and when discontent with the war became a majority sentiment, they wound up vindicated. When Watergate brought the resignation of President Richard Nixon and the landslide Democratic victory in the congressional elections of 1974, half a dozen baby-boomers, still in their 20s, entered Congress. The average age of America's representatives fell below 50 for the first time since the second world war.

Although the baby-boomers seemed committed to personal liberation and self-exploration in the 1960s, over time they proved a relatively conservative generation. By the 1980s, they had rallied behind Ronald Reagan and money-making. In the 1990s, they backed the abolition of the tax on inheritances, just in time to collect theirs. These days they back the ruthless protection of full retirement benefits.

At every step of his career, Joe Biden, born four years before the baby boom began, has been in a position to benefit from demographic change. Just as he is the oldest president in American history, he was in 1972 elected as one of the youngest senators in American history, indeed younger than the constitutionally mandated minimum age of 30. (He was able to take office because his 30th birthday fell in the eight weeks between election day and the Senate's swearing-in.)

His advantage, and the advantage of politicians like him, has been consolidated by the emergence of an American plutocracy and the role it plays in a money-saturated political system. In the United States, the people who bankroll campaigns do not just want to advance a cause - they want a personal relationship with the politician they're backing. That explains why so much fundraising takes place at fairly intimate dinners.

Now campaign-finance laws make it hard to transfer assets from one candidate to another. That is one reason why, after Biden's debate debacle, the howls of outrage from Democratic-leaning pundits about Biden's unsuitability as a candidate did not immediately bring constructive efforts to replace him. For a trust-fund activist or an oil mogul, an incumbent is an asset whose value must be protected deep into old age. And beyond, if possible: that is why the designation of offspring (such as George W. and Jeb Bush) and wives (such as Hillary Clinton and perhaps, some day, Michelle Obama) as successors has become acceptable, indeed preferable, among political powers-that-be. One can see why monarchy with familial succession is such a deep anthropological norm across societies - it gives those who have rallied behind a ruler the best chance of preserving their privileges.

Baby-boomers made up only 30% of voters in the most recent midterm elections of 2022. Their unceremonious dismissal from the stage of American public life is surely not far away. Yet their power remains entrenched for now. Why might this be?

Replacing leaders gets harder in a time of mass migration and inter-ethnic division. American voters always hesitate to pass the torch to the next generation; they may hesitate even more to pass the torch to a generation that includes newcomers from Latin America and Asia. Democrats are the party of migration and demographic change, trying to win an election at a time when Western voters are suspicious and even hostile to it - consider the recent elections across the European Union. Biden, with his half-century of Washington experience and middle-of-the-road demeanour, allows a dynamic party to reassure swing voters with a familiar face. When Donald Trump described Biden as "Sleepy Joe" in 2020, he may have been doing him a favour.

Gerontocracies, as noted, often aspire to lock an entire lost political order in place. If we thought of Biden as a gerontocrat, we would see his elevation as an attempt to revive the New Deal culture - a nation of traditional working-father-and-homemaking-mother families earning their livings in factories and on farms - that the party has jettisoned in recent decades, along with the working class that built its lives around it.

But that is not what is happening now. In the last election Democrats cobbled together a dynamic and fractious alliance of interest groups - single women, gays, government employees, tech entrepreneurs - committed to defeating Donald Trump. They had done this before, in the Obama-era bloc that the journalist Ronald Brownstein called the "coalition of the ascendant". But beyond their ascendance, these interest groups still don't have much in common, and in 2020 they had to come together during a summer of protests and riots over race and policing.

At the time, Biden was not particularly popular among Democratic primary voters. But he provided an image of continuity for a government of discontinuity and promised to reconcile the different wings of his coalition. This reconciliation still proves elusive. Someone who marches for George Floyd might not be committed to arming Ukraine or subsidising green-energy billionaires or keeping abortion legal. The extent of the challenge is visible in its intra-party strife over Israel, as well as the colossal deficits Biden has found it necessary to run up in order to maintain unity. You don't keep a coalition like this together by saying "no".

The problems with Biden are not the traditional problems with gerontocrats - it's not that he's running things like an old man or snoozing through important decisions. It's that the detail-orientation and hyperactivity of his administration leave the impression that he isn't running things at all. Things are being run by some younger people, whom none of us voted for and whose names we perhaps don't even know.

The American system right now is something very different from a gerontocracy, even if it is being disguised as one. For a country undergoing tremendous stress and change, America is responding with surprising vigour (consider Trump's covid-vaccine programme or Biden's green-energy and tech subsidies) and surprising aggression (consider Biden's eagerness to turn the Russian war against Ukraine into a Western war against Russia).

That gives something of a logic to the weird face-off between the two candidates. Biden is an old-fashioned person with a progressive and in many ways radical agenda. Trump is delivering promises of a restoration, even if he is not a person who would be deemed worthy of the Oval Office in the America his voters would like him to restore. Whichever side one prefers, there is nothing sleepy or crepuscular about any of it. Immoderation, impetuosity, egotism: the vices of the present day are those not of age but of youth. ■
summary: The article discusses the advanced age of America's political leaders, focusing on President Joe Biden's performance and the broader implications of having elderly politicians in power. Biden's frequent gaffes and confusion, highlighted during a June 27th debate, raise concerns about his capability to handle complex issues. The article contrasts Biden with other senior politicians like Donald Trump, Nancy Pelosi, and Mitch McConnell, noting that the U.S. political landscape is dominated by older leaders. This gerontocracy is seen as problematic, especially in a rapidly changing society. The article argues that while older leaders are traditionally valued for their wisdom and stability, the current situation reflects a deeper issue of generational stagnation, exacerbated by the baby-boomer generation's prolonged political dominance. Despite their age, these leaders are pushing radical agendas, indicating that the vices of today's politics are more akin to youthful impetuosity than the caution typically associated with old age.

title: London Playbook PM: It's the final countdown
body:
-- Rishi Sunak and Keir Starmer are preparing for their final rallies of the campaign.

-- Multiple polls are showing ever-worsening predictions for the Tories.

-- Even Boris Johnson's dad isn't following his son's advice to vote Conservative.

-- And neither is the Sun newspaper. The tabloid backed Labour.

-- Rishi Sunak experienced an insane meeting of minds on "This Morning." And revealed his on-brand favorite meal.

**A message from Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance supported by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation: Between 2000 and 2020 Gavi protected one billion children from vaccine-preventable diseases. With the UK's support, we can make our world safer by protecting more children against more diseases, faster than ever before.**

TOP OF THE NEWSLIST

IT'S THE FINAL COUNTDOWN: Rishi Sunak and Keir Starmer are preparing to make their final pitches to voters ... with three seat-level polls in the past hour predicting an ever-worsening night for the Conservatives.

First data point: The latest YouGov MRP poll dropped in the past few minutes showing an even worse result for the Conservatives than the pollster's previous research a couple of weeks ago. It predicts Labour winning 431 seats with the Tories on 102. That Conservative number is down from 108 in the previous YouGov MRP.

This is big: That would be a 212 majority for Keir Starmer -- the biggest Commons majority since 1832. The Lib Dems meanwhile are predicted to win 72 seats, the SNP 18 and Reform three.

Second data point: Another MRP poll for More in Common, in partnership with the News Agents podcast, predicts the Tories will win 126 seats and Labour 430 -- giving the new administration a majority of 210. That sounds like quite good news for the Tories in the current context ... until it's compared with the most recent More in Common MRP from two weeks ago, which predicted Sunak would end up with 155 seats and Labour 406.

The small print: There are 133 seats in the More in Common poll with majorities of less than 5 percent, meaning a last minute swing could well change the overall picture. And there are 52 seats effectively tied, including those of Conservative leadership hopeful Penny Mordaunt against Labour in Portsmouth North and Labour frontbencher Thangam Debbonaire against the Greens in Bristol Central.

Extras: The Lib Dems are set to win more than 50 seats, More in Common reckons, while the SNP is set to fall below 20. The pollster also predicts former Labour boss Jeremy Corbyn will win his Islington North seat, while Nigel Farage and Lee Anderson are set to win their respective Clacton and Ashfield targets for Reform. Full map here.

Third data point: The Conservatives have dropped a further two seats since last week in the latest MRP for Focaldata, also released this afternoon. The poll puts the Labour on 444 seats (down six on last week) and the Tories on 108, meaning a 238 majority for Starmer and co. The Lib Dems are the main beneficiaries of the shifting sands, up seven seats on 57, while the Reform has doubled its expectations in a week ... to two seats.

And there's more: There have been a whole bunch of voting intention polls in the past few hours too (those boring old normal polls we used to get excited about before the MRP bubble came along) predicting nothing less than a 17-point Labour lead.

Onwards to (not) victory! Sunak will nevertheless keep his duracell rabbit vibe going to the bitter end, hosting a rally at 8 p.m. tonight in Hampshire. Expect warnings about tax rises, supermajorities, increased legal and illegal migration and all the other things that are horrible when it's not the Tories doing them.

Supermajorities latest: Minister for the broadcast studios Mel Stride told Times Radio this morning Britain looks to be on the brink of "the largest landslide we will have ever seen," urging voters to consider "supporting the Conservative Party so we can hold this government to account going forward." Quite the line less than 24 hours before polls open.

Mixed messages: Appearing on "This Morning," erm, this morning, Sunak said Stride wasn't conceding defeat. The PM insisted he was "fighting hard for every vote" and that a few more ballots in the right places "can make the difference in this election." Easier said than done.

Still not giving up, honest: And in an interview with PA which landed in the last few minutes, the PM said he wasn't willing to reflect on his time in office while the election was ongoing. "As long as I can look myself in the mirror and know that I am working as hard as I can, doing what I believe is right for the country, that is how I get through," he said.

Don't believe the hype: Speaking to broadcasters during a campain event in Wales, Starmer said the Stride line was an effort in "voter suppression," adding : "It's trying to get people to stay at home rather than go out and vote." He said something or other about people who want change needing to vote for it.

Not bovverd: Starmer also told hacks Boris Johnson materializing on the campaign trail like a mirage in the dessert last night wasn't a concern. "Having argued for six weeks that they're chaotic and divided, to bring out exhibit A, with 24 hours to go, just vindicated the argument I've been making," he said. Steven Swinford has the behind-the-scenes on how Sunak talked BoJo into a campaign appearance.

Not to mention: Playbook PM remembers when BoJo was opening for all the final stump speeches Theresa May did in the 2017 election. And we all know how that ended. Even BoJo's dad ain't following his advice.

Last Starmer stump: The Labour leader is expected to appear at a rally in Worcestershire at around 8 p.m. too.

Making platforms for Nigel: Reform boss Nigel Farage will be doing his Donald Trump impressions at Clacton Pier from 6 p.m. for his last hurrah of the campaign. He's done his final campaign interview with Chris Hope of GB News (who else?) which should appear on the broadcaster around 7 p.m. Farage faced further accusations of hanging out with wrong 'uns this afternoon.

On the Ed one last time: Lib Dem boss Ed Davey has been in Hertfordshire with his second-in-command Daisy Cooper. He drove a tractor earlier with "he who dares wins" printed on it -- the line Michael Gove is said to have delivered to Cabinet when Rishi Sunak called the election. There's no doubt Davey has proved he has more daring balls than Gove during this campaign. Not least because Gove didn't even dare stand.

Back to the polls: While readers wait for those final campaign pitches, there has been shed loads more polling out since this morning, which is as good a form of entertainment as any -- including various interesting side-insights exclusive to Playbook PM.

Conservative Hail Mary pass: A good chunk of undecided voters could return to the Tories in vital seats, making the difference between election defeat and total wipeout, per new research by JL Partners shared with Playbook PM. Nine percent of voters in safe-ish Conservative seats are still undecided (slightly higher than in seats overall) and almost two-thirds of these undecideds voted Conservative in 2019.

Cold comfort: There are signs these late deciders are not yet ready to switch allegiance. Rishi Sunak's approval rating is at net -5 among this group and has improved over the campaign, compared with a score of -34 for Keir Starmer. Promising stuff for the Tories.

However: Another More in Common poll for the New Britain Project think tank and shared with Playbook PM showed Labour ahead of the Tories (and Reform) on various crucial metrics, such as having a long-term vision for Britain, competence, fixing problems, being stable and being good in a crisis.

And to make matters even worse ... more than a quarter of voters are planning to cast their ballot tactically, acording to research from Savanta for the Electoral Reform Society and shared with Playbook PM. That's up three points since the questin was asked at the start of the campaign. But (and this is quite the but) it's lower than at the same point before the 2019 election, when intention to vote tactically was at 30 percent. Would it be a huge surprise if all the noise about tactical voting comes to nothing again?

Still want more polling? More in Common boss Luke Tryl will be discussing his latest MRP data with UCL in a 6 p.m. webinar. Details here.

Polling product warning: It's well worth reading this thread from Savanta's Chris Hopkins, which does lots of important expectation management and tries to un-spin the inevitable spin from the parties once the actual results become clear.

DRIVETIME DEBRIEF

IT HAPPENED: The Sun backed Labour! The right-wing tabloid was never gonna be on the losing side, right? Its leader article for tomorrow says the Tories are "exhausted" after endless chaos. It gives qualified support to Keir Starmer, but argues "dragging his party back to the centre ground of British politics for the first time since Tony Blair was in No. 10, Sir Keir has won the right to take charge." More details on our liveblog.

Almost a clean sweep: There endeth the gospel according to Rupert Murdoch from the Sun perspective. Just the Times to go.

Not so Standard procedure: The Evening Standard backed Labour on its front page this afternoon. Is that another Boris Johnson snub against Rishi Sunak? The paper is majority owned by BoJo pal Evgeny Lebedev -- and the ex-PM even handed his bro a controversial peerage in 2020.

This one has to hurt: The paper of the financial sector, City A.M, also backed Labour, arguing the Conservative administration is "out of ideas, out of energy, and deserves to be out of office."

In other media news: Guido Fawkes totted up which Conservative and Labour frontbenchers spent most time on the airwaves through the campaign. For the Tories, there's a correlation between ministers in safe or safe-ish seats who live not too far from the broadcast studios in London.

HOW POLITICS REALLY WORKS: The New Statesman has a great list of the 103 professional lobbyists standing in the 2024 general election. It notes lobbyists are 27 times more likely than teachers to be candidates.

TRAMPLED BY TRUMP: A senior Donald Trump campaign aide shot down the Telegraph report from last night claiming Labour is in daily contact with those around the Republican candidate. Labour did not respond to a request for comment, and it's not clear who the opposition is claiming to be in regular touch with.

MEA CULPA: Emergency proxy votes are available only in limited circumstances, including in the event of a medical emergency, if an individual is away for work, or their ID has been lost, damaged or destroyed. Where a postal ballot pack has not yet arrived, electors should contact their returning officer before 5 p.m. on polling day and ask for it to be reissued. Apologies if all that wasn't clear last night.

SOCIAL (MEDIA) AFFAIRS

DAD VOTES: The Tories have been putting out attack ads about Reform aimed at men, picking up on comments candidates have made about women and asking: "Would your daughter want you to vote Reform?" See here from POLITICO's John Johnston.

INSANE MOMENTS IN BRITISH POLITICS ETC: This bonkers photo from the Rishi Sunak appearance on This Morning was getting lots of pickup on social media.

Also great sharing fodder: Rishi Sunak told the show his favorite food is ... sandwiches. Which kinda makes sense, seeing as sandwiches are the perfect meal for ambitious people on the go who don't have time to think about cooking and don't want sauce down their nice shirts.

Insane moments in British politics cont: The woman in the bonkers photo above was Becky Holt, otherwise known as "Britain's most tattooed mum," it appears. She told the Telegraph she agreed with Sunak that sandwiches are the best meal. "I'm totally with him on sandwiches being the best," she told the paper. "My favorite is bacon, lettuce and tomato." She added: "Rishi Sunak was gorgeous, he had beautiful skin, lovely eyes and teeth -- I'd love to give him a good sandwich." No prizes for guessing what she'd like to do with his beautiful skin.

And there's more: "I'm not into politics whatsoever. I know I should care, but I don't," Holt said, speaking for most of Britain. "I like the memes but other than that I have no interest."

Seriously, this stuff keeps coming: Asked which party leader she would get tattooed on her body, she said she would get Sunak. "I'd get a picture of his face and put a little caption saying 'when I was little I didn't get Sky TV,'" she said. Now that's cut through.

ASHWORTH IN WONDERLAND: When Labour HQ was too full during the campaign, the high command increased desk space via an overspill office in Waterloo. Which happened to be "Alice in Wonderland" themed. (H/t Dominic Hauschild.)

JEFFREY IN COURT: Former Democratic Unionist Leader Jeffrey Donaldson appeared in court in Newry, Northern Ireland, to be told he will face 18 charges including rape, gross indecency with a child and indecent assault on a female, with his likely plea date set for September 10. Asked if he had anything to say, Donaldson replied: "Not at this stage." His 58-year-old wife Eleanor, who stood beside her husband in the dock separated by a court official, faces five charges including abetting rape and cruelty to a person under 16 years old.

AROUND THE WORLD

IN AMERICA: President Joe Biden told an unnamed key ally he knows he might not be able to salvage his candidacy if he cannot convince the public he is up to the job -- the New York Times reported this afternoon.

FROM UKRAINE: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said Donald Trump should come forward with the plan the ex-president says he has to quickly end the war with Russia. "If Trump knows how to finish this war, he should tell us today," he told Bloomberg Television in Kyiv.

On the ground: At least five people were killed by a Russian drone and missile strike in the central city of Dnipro, with a further 47 people injured as shops, schools and hospitals were damaged -- via the BBC.

IN MAURITANIA: Three protestors died in detention after mass arrests during protests in the southern town of Kaédi. The protests erupted after President Mohamed Ould Ghazouani won a second term in office Sunday, with his main rival Biram Dah Abeid rejecting the result over alleged irregularities -- the Guardian has more.

**A message from Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance supported by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation: Between 2000 and 2020, Gavi protected one billion children from vaccine-preventable diseases, saving 17 million lives and generating US$220 billion in economic benefits in lower-income countries. With the UK's continued support, we can reach the next billion in half the time. Protecting more children against more diseases, faster than ever before, means keeping our world safe from infectious diseases. It means helping countries become self-sufficient and less dependent on aid. It means giving hope and opportunity to millions of people. Immunisation is one of the best buys in development, and as a founding donor, the UK has played a critical role in this success. With continued leadership by the UK, Gavi can immunise 500 million more children, saving over eight million lives. Learn more here.**

NEW GIG: Leveling Up department top man in the press team James Fowler is off to spin for the Met Police. Congrats! He joins a couple of other colleagues who made the same jump of late.

MEA CULPA: Playbook AM should have made clear Oliver Dowden's kind-of endorsement of Vicky Atkins as next leader was as he introduced her at an event in December. Dowden said he rated both her and Rishi Sunak as leadership material when the trio entered parliament together.

ON THIS DAY IN POLITICS: On July 3 1967 the News At 10 premiered on TV. On the same date in 2022 fresh allegations about Conservative MP Chris Pincher making unwanted advances towards men emerged -- the scandal helped bring down then Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
summary:
**Summary:**

As the UK election campaign nears its end, Rishi Sunak and Keir Starmer are making their final appeals to voters. Polls predict a significant defeat for the Conservatives, with Labour potentially securing a historic majority. The YouGov MRP poll forecasts Labour winning 431 seats to the Tories' 102, while other polls show similar trends. Even traditionally Conservative supporters, like Boris Johnson's father and the Sun newspaper, are backing Labour. Sunak remains determined, hosting a rally in Hampshire, while Starmer campaigns in Worcestershire. The election's outcome could reshape British politics, with implications for party leadership and future governance.

title: Lack of Nuclear Conflict Shelter Space Prompts Private Bunker Demand
body:
The lack of underground shelter space for protection during a nuclear conflict is prompting people to invest in private bunkers.

The "scare factor" from potential nuclear fallout, especially with the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict, is a major reason why individuals are preparing for the worst, according to Charles Hardman, who runs the company Subterranean Spaces.

Some of his clients include energy company directors, Middle Eastern royalty, and European car company owners.

He said that fear of nuclear conflict, especially due to the recent Russia-Ukraine war was a major reason for bunker purchases, though a desire to showcase wealth also played a role.

He said that very wealthy people wanted "to tick the box" with a Ferrari, an Aston Martin, a house in Europe, and a house in the UK.

But now, a nuclear bunker is "something they can tick the box with," he said.

Mr. Hardman, who also has quite a lot of inquiries overseas, in Europe and Saudi Arabia, said that demand had "plateaued" in England, in part due to the fact that news coverage of the Ukraine war has dropped.

"The only reason people call up is if they get worried," he said.

"It's the wrong time; it's too late then. These things take eight to ten months to a year to build. People should be preparing now. The whole of Europe is getting them done," he added, citing Sweden, Switzerland, and Germany as examples.

Though he warned that in the UK there's no preparation. "There's nothing," he said.

"Israel has to have a safe room for every property. China and Russia have built vast bunkers for their populations, and yet, in the UK, they're like, 'No, we don't need bunkers,'" he said.

Mr. Thompson's company fills a niche by building smaller, more affordable bunkers, ranging from £20,000 to £150,000.

"You tend to have people who build bunkers for billionaires and millionaires, some of these are extremely lavish, with cinemas and swimming pools. But that's not what the everyday person can afford," he said.

Though he said that the growing interest due to increased awareness of potential conflicts.

"More and more people are waking up to the fact that we are basically marching towards World War Three between NATO and Russia," he said.

Nuclear war followed by climate change were people's biggest concerns.

"We had them in World War Two, Anderson shelters, of course, they made a couple of million, but they did save millions of lives," he said.

However he explained that the difference between now and then is that the humble World War II Anderson shelter was designed to offer British householders an afternoon of protection during bomb raids.

But in a fallout shelter, where you must hide from potential radiation, people may need to stay for two weeks or longer. Therefore, it has to be comfortable to live in, with sleeping quarters, cooking facilities, washing and bathing amenities, and entertainment and games etc.

"We had fallout from Chernobyl land in Wales, and we still have to scan the sheep today for radiation," he said.

Mr. Thompson's wife, a trained psychologist, provides video content to help people cope during crises in a potential bunker situation.

He said that planning permission is growing and depends on "what area you live in and who you are." However, some clients may wish to remain tight-lipped about such a project.

"Do you want to advertise your bunker? Because when it all goes wrong, they are going to be in your bunker -- and if you've only built one for your family you can't support half the neighbourhood," he said.
summary: The ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict has heightened fears of nuclear fallout, leading to increased demand for private bunkers, according to Charles Hardman of Subterranean Spaces. His clients include energy company directors, Middle Eastern royalty, and European car company owners, who are motivated by both fear and a desire to showcase wealth. While demand has plateaued in England due to reduced news coverage, interest remains high in Europe and Saudi Arabia. Hardman warns that the UK is unprepared compared to countries like Sweden, Switzerland, and Germany. His company offers more affordable bunkers, ranging from £20,000 to £150,000, unlike the lavish bunkers for the ultra-wealthy. He emphasizes the need for comfortable living conditions in bunkers, as people may need to stay for extended periods. Hardman's wife, a psychologist, provides crisis coping content for bunker occupants. Planning permission for bunkers varies, and some clients prefer to keep their projects private to avoid unwanted attention during crises.

title: The dragnet approach to the EU individual sanctions regime is failing
body:
Dr Moshe Kantor's case clearly demonstrates a cleanup of the list is long overdue. Those who deserve sanctions should remain, while those who were caught up in the overly tenacious initial compilation should be removed, Eldad Beck writes.

Since the very beginning of the Russia-Ukraine war in February 2022, the European Union has taken many measures and posed sanctions against Russia and those deemed to be "supporting, financing or implementing actions" in the war effort.

Unfortunately, in a hurried approach, some of the bureaucrats who put together the list and the criteria for applying personal sanctions against hundreds of individuals took what now appears to be a scorched earth policy. On many occasions, they seemingly relied on simple Google searches and Russia's rich list, much of which would not have stood up in court.

In fact, in April, this was proven true.

Two individuals, Mikhail Fridman and Petr Aven, successfully proved before the European Court of Justice that the European Council had not presented enough evidence to establish that they met the necessary bar of being involved in efforts that "undermine or threaten the territorial integrity, sovereignty and independence of Ukraine".

Now, another hearing on one of the most egregious cases to date could deal another blow to the sanctions regime.

On 19 June, the General Court, the Court of Justice of the European Union, held a hearing on the case of Dr Moshe Kantor, former President of the European Jewish Congress (EJC), who stepped back from his position following the Council's decision to include him on the list of individual sanctions in 2022.

Kantor is the only democratically elected leader of a European minority community who was included on the individual sanctions list. In his role as a Jewish leader, he met with many European heads of state, European decision-makers and opinion-shapers.

For his activities, the promotion of tolerance and fighting against xenophobia and antisemitism, Dr Kantor received, over the years, state honours from, amongst others, Poland, Ukraine, Italy, Romania, Belgium, Austria and France.

Ironically, French President Emmanuel Macron awarded Kantor with the title of Commandeur de la Légion d'Honneur only a few weeks before France voted, as a member of the EU Council, to sanction him because of Kantor's presumed economic ties with the Kremlin.

During the hearing at the EU Court, Kantor's defence team stressed that the whole process against Kantor was born in sin and haste and created an "exceptional situation", in which Kantor is sanctioned despite the fact that he has been living for decades away from Russia, has dedicated his life for the fight against antisemitism, promoting tolerance and ensuring the security of Jewish communities in Europe.

Moreover, insisted the defence, the sanctions were renewed time and time again since September 2022 with an "incomprehensible insistence" despite all evidence provided to the Council, showing that Kantor ceased all his business activities even before the Russian annexation of Crimea in 2014.

After the EU Council legal team made its case, clearly exasperated, one of the judges asked again for evidence for the "mechanisms of benefit" between Kantor and Russian President Vladimir Putin, a crucial element in the case for sanctions. The Council's lawyers responded that all the evidence had previously been presented and were unable or unwilling to add anything new.

To demonstrate another problematic part of the accusations against him, Kantor's legal team brought up the fact that the first official file against him stated that he had "Jewish-Russian" nationality, a highly problematic and discriminatory appellation used by the Nazis against Jews in the 20th century.

Kantor was the only person on the EU sanctions list whose religious affiliation was referred to. This "mistake" brought the President of the European Council, Charles Michel, to apologise to Kantor.

A letter signed by Michel0s Head of Cabinet, Frederic Bernard, dated 27 July 2022, explains: "We sincerely regret the error that has been made by the responsible service with regards to your nationality in the evidence pack and has been rectified. The correct version of the document is enclosed herewith."

While this was the most controversial, it was not the only error in the case against Kantor.

According to numerous articles and experts who have assessed the working files of some of those sanctioned, the evidence compiled was "slipshod", "shaky" and "embarrassing".

The document used as a basis to sanction Kantor in 2022 contains only 64 pages and includes just eight articles and websites, six of which are machine-translated versions of Russian-language originals. The bulk of the packet consists of screenshots of entire articles, with relevant passages highlighted in yellow.

Two of the articles, on the Russian web portal Rambler and outlet Vecherniy Murmansk, are labeled on the websites as an "advertisement" or "paid advertisement", a description that was not included in the evidence packet. It is unknown who paid for these advertisements.

Some of these articles are what can only be described as "fake news" pieces, which antisemitically accused Kantor of using his position as a Jewish leader to distort the memory of the Holocaust and minimise antisemitism for personal gain.

Accepting these types of articles at face value, knowing they are paid advertisements on sometimes obscure websites by unknown figures, can themselves be construed as antisemitic.

The file also mistakenly lists Kantor as a shareholder of Acron, a Russian-based mineral fertiliser producer, instead of as an ultimate beneficiary.

On the point of Kantor's relationship with Putin, he has not held any business position in Russia for 30 years and has devoted all of his time and efforts to leading the European Jewish community over the last 20 years. No other person on the list is comparable to him in these respects. All the other people listed as "businesspersons" have either business positions or capital holdings in Russia.

The Court has even annulled the Council's decision to retain a businessperson on the sanctions list who left his position a few months before the renewal, as was the case for Alexander Shulgin last September.

As Kantor's legal team made clear, contrary to many other individuals on the sanctions list, Kantor was never invited to the numerous business forum meetings organised by the Kremlin for leading businessmen in Russia.

In the hearing, Kantor's legal team asserted that the Council's supposed case is simply based on the idea that one cannot be wealthy and of Russian origin without being a "leading" businessperson involved in a sector providing a substantial source of revenue to Russia.

Kantor's lawyers spoke about a "real blindness" of the Council in front of facts and of "impossible scenarios," accusing Kantor of minimising the dimension of antisemitism in Russia or disproportionally promoting Russia´s role during WWII for personal gains

The EU Council's legal team admitted several times that mistakes were made in the preparation of Kantor´s sanctions file regarding his nationality and the claim that he was a shareholder of the Acron group.

The question that requires answering is why Kantor was sanctioned in the first place and remains on the list.

Some have argued that his tireless campaigns for the security of Jewish communities, against antisemitism, as well as fighting Holocaust distortion and denial over the last 20 years, have fueled resentment against Kantor, and some old and baseless allegations against him are now weaponised.

The jurist Regis Bismuth, professor at the Sciences Po Law School in Paris and Director of Studies of the French Branch of International Law Association (ILA) and an expert on EU sanctions sees a structural failure in the way the sanctions list was prepared, and in the case of Kantor in particular.

"I think that it is interesting to place this case in the larger background of how sanctions are adopted by the EU Council. In 2022, hundreds of people were listed on the EU restriction measures list. Of course, some of them are deeply connected with the Russian regime, but not all of them," Professor Bismuth said.

"The files on the first group of sanctioned individuals were completed in just a few days. We do not have information on how files justifying individual sanctions were made. We have to keep in mind that many people were put on the list very quickly and often on the basis of information gathered from newspapers, sometimes Russian publications that are not completely reliable, or from social media."

"With Dr Kantor, there is a clear manifest error of assessment. What is particularly shocking about the case of Dr Kantor is that the file is relatively empty, and he appears to have been listed on the basis of his alleged wealth".

Regardless of the motivations for placing and maintaining Kantor on the sanctions list, the public hearing at the General Court laid bare many problems of the individual sanctions regime.

That is why a cleanup of the list is long overdue. Those who deserve sanctions should remain, while those who were caught up in the overly tenacious initial compilation should be removed.

The EU sanctions regime has suffered some recent blows. Disassociating itself from those who clearly have no place on the list would be a good start in its reputational restoration.

Eldad Beck is an Israeli journalist.
summary:
The article by Eldad Beck critiques the European Union's individual sanctions regime, highlighting the case of Dr. Moshe Kantor as a prime example of its flaws. Since the Russia-Ukraine war began in February 2022, the EU imposed sanctions on many individuals, but the process was rushed and often relied on unreliable sources. Dr. Moshe Kantor, a prominent Jewish leader and former President of the European Jewish Congress, was sanctioned due to presumed economic ties with the Kremlin, despite his long-standing efforts against antisemitism and his lack of business activities in Russia for decades.

In June 2023, the General Court of the European Union held a hearing on Kantor's case, where his defense argued that the sanctions were based on erroneous and discriminatory information. The EU Council's legal team admitted to several mistakes in Kantor's file. The case underscores broader issues with the EU's sanctions list, which was hastily compiled and included individuals based on flimsy evidence. The article calls for a thorough review and cleanup of the sanctions list to restore the regime's credibility.

title: The United States, NATO, and Geopolitical Strategies: Q&A with Ann Marie Dailey
body:
Ann Marie Dailey serves as an engineer captain in the U.S. Army Reserves

Ann Marie Dailey is an expert on some of the most pressing questions now facing the United States and its global allies: How to help Ukraine. What to expect from Russia. How to position NATO for the next 75 years.

She's a policy researcher at RAND and a nonresident senior fellow at the Atlantic Council. For more than two decades, she has studied the political, military, and economic drivers that underpin global security. She served as a senior adviser to the Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs on both Russia and Ukraine, as well as on NATO relations with Ukraine and Georgia. She also joined the U.S. Army in 2015 and now serves as an engineer captain in the Reserves.

If you look at the battlefield, there's an artificial inflection point that's been brought about by the long delay in approving more U.S. aid to Ukraine. The Russians are going on the offensive. But if the Ukrainians are able to fend them off through the rest of 2024, then I think systemic factors are going to turn in Ukraine's favor. Russia will face increasing difficulties in its defense production, especially its production of armored vehicles. You'll see increasing U.S. and European production coming online. You'll see the introduction of F-16s, which will at least give Ukraine some additional flexibility. Ukraine's strategy through 2024 is going to be to play defense, and hopefully that puts them on a footing for a possible offensive in 2025.

There are people in Washington who say we can't keep supporting Ukraine because it undermines our ability to prepare for China. But if we're looking at a potential future conflict with China, there are two worlds we could fight it in.

One is a world in which Ukraine loses. In that world, all of our European allies are going to be laser-focused on protecting themselves from the next attack from Russia. The United States will be more diplomatically isolated, because those 31 NATO allies are going to be much more concerned about their own security than about helping the United States in a fight against China.

The other world is one in which Ukraine wins. Then you have a Ukraine that is going to be the largest and most capable army in Europe acting as a bulwark against Russian aggression. That gives you a strong European flank to the United States' east. You have countries that are confident not only in their own security but in the collective capability of NATO to deter and defeat aggression. They are going to be more willing to contribute if the U.S. finds itself in a war in the Indo-Pacific. This idea that somehow helping Ukraine leaves us less prepared for a war in China is just seeing the world as flat when it's not.

It needs to either bring them in or make it clear they're not going to be a member. Leaving them in diplomatic limbo just makes things worse for Ukraine and undermines NATO. Personally, I think Ukraine must become a member, but a bigger question right now is, What does NATO need to do to ensure Ukraine wins this war?

A victorious, unified Ukraine would be the most capable military in Europe, and at that point it would just be foolish not to bring them in.

Increase its defense industrial base. As long as Russia sees that it's outproducing the combined capabilities of the United States and its European allies in NATO, it will see that it can continue to fight this war. As soon as the United States and Europe match those numbers, the calculus changes.

I'd also like to see NATO air defenses providing a shield over western Ukraine. You've seen Russia fire missiles and attack drones that actually overfly NATO territory. And rather than air defenses from those nations firing at them and shooting them down, they've relied on Ukraine to use its air defenses to do that. The idea that you wouldn't protect NATO skies by engaging those missiles and drones -- it's not only not helping Ukraine, but it's undermining NATO's Article 5 deterrence. I'd also support France's proposal to start bringing troops into western Ukraine, far from the front lines, to provide training on the ground to Ukrainians.

The same way they've responded so far, which is with a lot of nuclear bluster. They know as soon as they mention tactical nuclear weapons, it will freeze decisionmakers in some capitals.

We're seeing an increase in threats below the level of military action -- massive amounts of disinformation, illicit finances being used to undermine political processes. NATO has been so successful over the past 75 years that its enemies are trying to use other ways to attack or undermine the alliance. It's going to struggle to define what constitutes an attack, and then to ensure it has the capabilities it needs to respond. You've seen China and Russia engage in these threats below the level of what you would consider conventional military actions. NATO needs to make itself a harder target by developing more capabilities that are below the threshold of direct military confrontation and demonstrating a willingness to use them. But it needs to do that while also upholding the democratic ideas of freedom and openness.

I had considered joining at several points in my life. Then, in 2015, I was the senior adviser on Russia strategy, and I'd participate in these wargames, where Russia was attacking NATO. I was always advocating for more NATO forces forward and, in particular, more U.S. forces. We also consistently found that the U.S. Army had not nearly enough large-scale engineering capabilities. My mom used to always say, 'If you want something done right, then do it yourself.' I decided to join as an Army engineer, not just because I thought it was important for me personally. I was advocating moving forward U.S. military forces, essentially as a tripwire, and I wasn't comfortable doing that if I wasn't willing to put myself in that position.

One thing the Army has taught me is how the military approaches risk. It doesn't get to decide which missions to pursue. It just has to look at how to assess and mitigate risk, with the understanding that it will always have to accept a certain level of risk to complete the mission. That's something military leaders understand very well, but it's not necessarily deeply engrained in civilian culture. It's also helped me think more broadly about defense and security problems -- not just looking at things and platforms, but at people and leadership.

I was a big Detroit Red Wings fan when I was a kid. Hockey fans might remember, back in the '90s, the Russian Five. It was this line of five Russian players who were brought to the Red Wings and ended up winning several Stanley Cups. Growing up, I would watch Tom Clancy films with my dad, where the Russians were always the bad guys; and then I would watch the Detroit Red Wings, where the Russians were the good guys. It caused this cognitive dissonance in my mind, this contradiction that I wanted to study more. So I pursued Russian studies and international relations in college, and I guess the rest is history.
summary: Ann Marie Dailey, an engineer captain in the U.S. Army Reserves and a policy researcher at RAND, discusses the geopolitical strategies of the United States and NATO, particularly in relation to Ukraine and Russia. Dailey emphasizes the importance of continued U.S. aid to Ukraine, predicting that if Ukraine can defend against Russian offensives through 2024, systemic factors will favor Ukraine. She argues that a Ukrainian victory would strengthen NATO and better prepare the U.S. for potential conflicts with China. Dailey also advocates for NATO to increase its defense industrial base and provide air defenses over western Ukraine. She highlights the need for NATO to adapt to non-military threats like disinformation and illicit finances. Dailey's insights are informed by her extensive experience, including her advisory role in the Department of Defense and her military service.

title: A Test of Leadership and Resolve
body:
As the conflict in Ukraine intensifies, the Western world confronts a pivotal moment that will define its global leadership for years to come. The decision to withhold military aid risks not only undermining solidarity but also signalling weakness that could embolden further aggression and escalate conflicts into neighbouring regions.

Western nations must understand the prolonged nature of the standoff with Russia. Doubts about Russia's future must be dispelled, and fears of its potential dissolution should not dictate policy. The current state of Russia, maintaining a quasi-imperial stance, poses significant threats to global security, including the uncontrolled proliferation of missile and nuclear technologies among adversarial states.

Failure to support Eastern European democracies sends a clear message globally that the era of Western dominance in global affairs is waning. This reluctance could potentially lead to a new era of instability characterised by localised conflicts and the ominous spectre of a major global war, possibly involving nuclear weapons.

The current ceasefire in Ukraine may prove to be a precursor to potential broader global conflicts. Observers note with concern the West's apparent reluctance or inability to address global challenges. This hesitance emboldens proponents of global realignment, who are increasingly stirring conflicts in the Middle East, East and South Asia, and the Persian Gulf. Russia's actions in Ukraine serve as a catalyst, encouraging proxies worldwide to challenge the existing global order.

The West is currently being tested on its ability to confront contemporary challenges decisively. Failure to do so could lead to scenarios where critical international corridors, such as the Suwalki Corridor, will fall under threat, or where aggression against Baltic states becomes a reality.

Russian society's deep-seated resentment and nostalgia for its former imperial status exacerbate global tensions. Western democracies must acknowledge their historical responsibilities and the immense international pressures they will face should they fail to adequately support Ukraine with the necessary military aid.

Reduced aid to Ukraine not only places the United States and other Western nations under international scrutiny but also shifts the burden of historical responsibility onto them for potentially exacerbating a global crisis.

It is crucial for NATO to maintain comprehensive support particularly through military aid to Ukraine. The economic and strategic costs of countering Russian ambitions in Ukraine far outweigh the costs of preventive measures.

It is not solely Ukraine's struggle; the democratic free world must adopt a resolute stance against the current regime in Moscow. This includes setting clear conditions for ending the conflict, maximising Ukraine's military capabilities, and diplomatically isolating Russia to prevent future aggression.

Timely provision of arms and ammunition to Ukraine is critical to avoid scenarios where NATO must invoke Article 5 of its Treaty as a last resort.

The West faces a critical juncture where its decisions will resonate globally. By unequivocally supporting Ukraine with military aid it needs, the West can demonstrate its commitment to international stability and reaffirm its leadership in an increasingly tumultuous world. The consequences of indecision or half-hearted support would be catastrophic, spawning a dangerous new global order that would threaten peace and security worldwide.
summary:
The article "A Test of Leadership and Resolve" discusses the critical moment facing Western nations as the conflict in Ukraine escalates. The West's decision to withhold military aid risks undermining solidarity and signaling weakness, potentially leading to further aggression and regional conflicts. The prolonged standoff with Russia, which maintains a quasi-imperial stance, poses significant global security threats, including the proliferation of missile and nuclear technologies.

Failure to support Eastern European democracies could signal the decline of Western dominance, leading to instability and possibly a major global war. The current ceasefire in Ukraine might precede broader conflicts, with the West's hesitance emboldening global realignment proponents, stirring conflicts in various regions. The West's ability to confront these challenges is being tested, with potential threats to critical international corridors and Baltic states.

Russian society's nostalgia for its imperial past exacerbates tensions, and Western democracies must recognize their historical responsibilities. Reduced aid to Ukraine places the West under scrutiny and shifts historical responsibility onto them for potentially worsening the crisis. NATO's comprehensive support, particularly military aid, is crucial to counter Russian ambitions and prevent future aggression.

The article emphasizes that supporting Ukraine is not just about Ukraine's struggle but about the democratic free world taking a resolute stance against Moscow's regime. Timely military aid is essential to avoid invoking NATO's Article 5. The West's decisions at this juncture will have global repercussions, and unequivocal support for Ukraine is necessary to maintain international stability and reaffirm Western leadership. Indecision or half-hearted support could lead to a dangerous new global order threatening worldwide peace and security.

title: The Future of NATO
body:
To mark NATO's 75th Anniversary summit in Washington, D.C., the Quincy Institute invited leading U.S. and European analysts to comment on the future of the alliance. While differing greatly in their assessment both of NATO's role to date and of how they would like to see it develop in the future, all agree that NATO is facing an exceptionally difficult and dangerous period in its history.

NATO likes to describe itself as "the most successful alliance in history" not because it won a war, but because during the Cold War it deterred a Soviet attack on Western Europe and thereby prevented a new world war. What is too often forgotten, however, is that war was prevented not just by NATO solidarity, but also by NATO caution. Successive U.S. administrations -- fully backed by their European allies -- rejected calls for aggressive policies aimed at "rolling back" Soviet power in Eastern Europe.

Since the end of the Cold War, by contrast, NATO has become committed to rolling back Russian power even in former Soviet countries on Russia's own borders. As a result of the clash between this and Moscow's determination to maintain a sphere of influence, NATO now finds itself in a proxy conflict with Moscow on the European Continent itself. If this turns into direct war, there is a good chance that it will end with a nuclear exchange. At that point, the question of the future role of NATO will become meaningless, if only because there will be nobody left to ask it.

If direct war can be avoided, most analysts predict that mutual hostility between Russia and the West will continue for the foreseeable future, and will involve the risk of further clashes around Russia's borders -- for example, over the future of Belarus and Russian access to the exclave of Kaliningrad across NATO territory in Lithuania. How great this threat will be depends on how the war in Ukraine eventually ends, and whether it is through a compromise peace or a petering out into an endless semifrozen conflict.

Analysts agree that NATO's European members will definitely try to rearm, especially if Donald Trump is reelected and U.S. commitment to Europe seems uncertain. Their efforts in this direction will, however, be hampered by economic stagnation, the conflicting demands of increasingly endangered budgets for health and social welfare, and the resistance of European countries to pooling their military production. In an effort to please Washington and ensure that the U.S. maintains its military presence in Europe, NATO is also likely to make public gestures toward a global role and the containment of China.

If the U.S. does pull back from Europe to any significant extent, NATO is likely to abandon its expansionist program of recent decades and limit itself to the defense of its existing members. This shift would, however, lead to considerable tensions between NATO members over policy toward Russia.

One notable result of the war in Ukraine has been the almost complete disappearance from NATO discussions of the threat of climate change, previously described as "existential." Nor does NATO have any strategy for the stabilization of countries to its south, or for addressing illegal migration across the Mediterranean. A few decades from now, however, the growth of these dangers may render many of NATO's existing preoccupations irrelevant.

- Anatol Lieven, Eurasia Program Director, Quincy Institute

Since the end of the Cold War, NATO has gone through many incarnations: NATO, the agent of transformation to bring Eastern Europe into the league of Western democracies. NATO, the fighter in the war against terrorism. NATO, the cybersleuth. The democracy-builder. The rules-based order enforcer.

And finally, at its 75 anniversary, NATO seems to be going back to its original mission: a collective defense pact to keep Europe safe -- and Russia out.

It is not surprising that the Russian invasion of Ukraine has energized the organization and reaffirmed the importance of Article 5 to all member states, big or small. NATO is no longer "brain-dead" and certainly has the capacity to deter Russia from attacking its member states.

But there still is much to do for the alliance to retain its relevance into the future.

The first is creation of benchmarks and incentives for members to do more for their own defense, so Europe can reduce its reliance on the United States as its sole security guarantor. No matter who gets to the White House in November, American public sentiment is shifting in ways that are certain to have long-term implications for U.S. commitment to European security.

At a time when Washington views China and the Indo-Pacific as the foremost strategic challenge, Europeans need to develop industrial capabilities so as to have the freedom to make independent decisions for their own destiny. That inevitably means increasing military spending and manufacturing to complement the U.S. role in European security today and develop more autonomous reflexes tomorrow.

NATO also needs to have a clear-eyed view of what its endgame in Ukraine is. Despite the slogan "Ukraine's defense is Europe's defense," Ukraine's Western backers do not have a unified vision for where Ukraine fits in Europe's security. While supporting Ukraine's ability to defend itself against Russian aggression has been critical for the alliance, given that Russia is far from losing the war, it's time to start thinking of how this war ends -- in ways that preserve Ukraine's sovereignty and build a new security architecture for Europe.

Ukraine's theory of victory is increasingly looking unachievable to its Western backers. It's not hard to imagine negotiations for a ceasefire -- even with continued Russian occupation in parts of Ukraine -- at some point over the next few years. The U.S. and its allies need to be able to provide sufficient security guarantees for Ukraine, so its leaders and society have the confidence to accept a bitter peace -- and embark toward a more desirable future.

That means a smaller but stronger Ukraine -- and NATO can be a critical piece of that.

What role NATO plays in negotiations to end the war will define the future of the alliance -- and the nature of strategic stability with a nuclear Russia. If NATO can play some role in the creation of a postconflict Ukraine, even in the absence of full membership for Ukraine, it will remain relevant in Europe's future security architecture.

Of course, none of this might happen. Europe may remain divided on the question of strategic autonomy, with many member states following the U.S. lead on geopolitical challenges. There may not be consensus inside the alliance for an active role for an endgame in Ukraine -- leaving the matter entirely to Washington. America's strategic involvement with the Indo-Pacific might make individual member states more eager to strike bilateral arrangements with Washington -- hollowing out NATO's core mission or creating an internal constituency that wants to steer the alliance more toward greater competition with China.

That, I am afraid, would mean that NATO's perpetual search for a mission will continue into its fourth quarter-century and well into the next generation.

Asli Aydintasbas is a Visiting Fellow at the Brookings Institution's foreign policy program and a Senior Associate Fellow at the European Council on Foreign Relations.'

In the European theater, conventional deterrence and defense should be ensured by Europeans. The 300,000 troops in a high state of readiness that the NATO New Force Model envisages on the eastern flank should be European troops. And they should need but a single American to be fully operational: SACEUR.

As it is, however, those 300,000 troops will still be dependent on American strategic enablers: intelligence, transport, deep strike, etc. Therefore, the European allies should go beyond the capability targets that NATO has currently assigned to them, and acquire all the necessary enablers themselves. That will undoubtedly require a collective effort, such as German Chancellor Scholz's Sky Shield initiative for a unified European air defense system.

That is where the European Union can help. Not in trying to align capability development and defense planning of its member states under the E.U. flag. After exactly 25 years (the Common Security and Defence Policy was launched in 1999), it is clear that nations do not want this. But the E.U. does have instruments that work, or can work: the European Defence Fund to invest in research and industry and the Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO) to build modular multinational capabilities. Those should be put to use to help the European allies build a comprehensive, full-spectrum force package within NATO.

If the Europeans managed to achieve this, this force package would constitute a tangible European pillar of NATO, in terms of capabilities. The U.S. should fully support such a move, and refrain from irritating allies by seeing everything in terms of defense industrial interests. If Europeans spend more money, of course they will want to spend more (not all) of that on European equipment. Washington needs Europe to do more, for it will free up conventional military resources for its own priorities in Asia, while the American nuclear umbrella remains the ultimate guarantee.

Indeed, it is precisely because President Obama in 2012 already made Asia into the U.S.' No. 1 priority that Europeans must build a complete pillar within NATO. Twelve years later, it is about time the European allies stop convincing themselves that whatever happens, the U.S. cavalry will always be there. The reality is that in case of simultaneous wars in Europe and Asia, the U.S. is likely to prioritize the latter. Moreover, E.U. member states can only confidently support E.U. candidate country Ukraine (and Moldova and Georgia) without having to fear direct Russian retaliation, because NATO provides deterrence -- the conventional part of which Europeans must in the end ensure themselves.

An alliance that rests both on the U.S. and on an autonomous European pillar would be a much more balanced, and therefore more healthy alliance. But the Europeans should also build this pillar to prepare for less-healthy scenarios. If domestic politics lead the U.S. to reduce its commitment to NATO, the Europeans should be ready to seamlessly take over any task that the U.S. might withdraw from. Strategy is all about being prepared to uphold your interests, whatever comes to pass.
